title: Completely Dead Battery — No Dash Lights, No Crank
symptom_short: No interior/dash lights, no crank, totally dead

likely_causes.cause: Battery fully discharged or failed internally
likely_causes.notes: Battery may have an internal open cell even if it shows voltage at rest.

likely_causes.cause: Loose or corroded battery terminals
likely_causes.notes: A loose clamp can mimic a dead battery.

likely_causes.cause: Main fuse/fusible link open
likely_causes.notes: Especially after jump-start mistakes or shorts.

recommended_checks: Check battery terminals for looseness/corrosion (white/green crust).
Measure battery voltage (healthy ~12.4–12.7V engine OFF).
Try jump start; if it starts, test charging system and parasitic draw.
Inspect main fuse/fusible link near battery/under-hood fuse box.
safety_warning: Avoid repeated jump starts without fixing the cause; reverse polarity can damage modules and cause fire risk.

title: Battery Dies Overnight (Parasitic Drain — Basic)
symptom_short: Battery repeatedly dead after sitting overnight

likely_causes.cause: Interior/trunk/glovebox light staying on
likely_causes.notes: Very common, especially with faulty latches.

likely_causes.cause: Aftermarket accessory (alarm, amp, dashcam) not sleeping
likely_causes.notes: Wired incorrectly to constant power.

likely_causes.cause: Aging battery can’t hold charge
likely_causes.notes: Typical life 3–5 years depending on climate/usage.

recommended_checks: Check battery age and do a load test (parts stores often do this).
Verify all lights turn off after closing doors/trunk.
If possible, measure key-off draw after 30–60 minutes (goal often < 50 mA on many cars).
Temporarily unplug aftermarket devices and retest overnight.
safety_warning: Frequent jump-starting can stress electronics; avoid being stranded in unsafe locations.

title: Advanced Parasitic Draw — Module Staying Awake
symptom_short: Battery drains in hours; car may behave “awake” after shutdown
symptom_patterns: battery drains in a few hours

likely_causes.cause: Stuck relay (cooling fan, fuel pump, blower, etc.)
likely_causes.notes: Relay contacts can weld shut.

likely_causes.cause: Body control module not entering sleep mode (network issue)
likely_causes.notes: Door switch input or CAN traffic can keep modules awake.

likely_causes.cause: Shorted alternator diode causing backfeed
likely_causes.notes: Can drain battery even with good alternator output.

recommended_checks: Measure key-off draw after modules should be asleep; then pull fuses one-by-one to isolate circuit.
Feel for warm relays/modules after shutdown (careful).
Test alternator for diode leakage/AC ripple.
Scan for network errors or modules not sleeping (advanced scan tool).
safety_warning: Do not keep replacing batteries without finding the draw; overheating wiring/relays is possible.

title: Single Click or Rapid Clicking — No Crank
symptom_short: Clicks but engine does not crank

likely_causes.cause: Weak battery / low voltage under load
Corroded terminals or poor ground connection
likely_causes.notes: High resistance can prevent starter current.

likely_causes.cause: Failing starter/solenoid

recommended_checks: Observe if lights dim heavily when cranking.
Clean/tighten terminals and check engine-to-chassis ground strap.
Measure battery voltage while cranking (dropping below ~9.6V often indicates weak battery).
Tap starter lightly (only if safe) as a temporary diagnostic clue.
safety_warning: Avoid long crank attempts (no more than 10 seconds) to prevent cable/starter overheating.

title: No Crank, No Click (But Dash Has Power)
symptom_short: Dash lights on but nothing happens at START
symptom_patterns: dash lights on but no crank

likely_causes.cause: Neutral safety switch / PRNDL range switch issue
likely_causes.notes: Try starting in Neutral if automatic.

likely_causes.cause: Bad starter relay or ignition switch
Immobilizer/key not recognized
likely_causes.notes: Common with push-button systems and weak key fob battery.

recommended_checks: Try starting in Neutral (automatic) or press clutch fully (manual).
Check for security/immobilizer warning light messages.
Swap starter relay with an identical relay (for test only) if available.
Try spare key or replace key fob battery.
safety_warning: Avoid bypassing safety interlocks; improper jumpers can cause vehicle movement or electrical damage.

title: Cranks Strongly But Will Not Start (Electrical/Control Related)
symptom_short: Engine turns over but never fires

likely_causes.cause: Ignition system power loss (relay/fuse) or no spark
Crankshaft/camshaft position sensor failure
likely_causes.notes: Often no RPM signal while cranking.

likely_causes.cause: Immobilizer preventing injector pulse
likely_causes.notes: Security light may flash.

recommended_checks: Scan for codes (P0335/P0340 etc.).
Confirm fuel pump prime sound (key ON).
Check engine RPM on scan tool while cranking (0 RPM suggests crank sensor).
Check relevant fuses/relays (ECM, ignition, fuel pump).
safety_warning: Avoid excessive cranking; it can flood the engine and overheat the starter.

title: Battery/Charging Light On While Driving
symptom_short: Battery light on; voltage may be low

likely_causes.cause: Alternator not charging (failed regulator/diodes)
Loose/slipping serpentine belt
likely_causes.notes: May squeal; belt tensioner could be weak.

likely_causes.cause: Corroded main charging cables or grounds
likely_causes.notes: Voltage drop reduces charging at battery.

recommended_checks: Measure voltage engine running (typical 13.5–14.8V depending on system).
Inspect belt condition and tension.
Check for hot/burnt smell near alternator wiring and battery cables.
Have charging system load-tested.
safety_warning: The engine can stall once the battery depletes. Avoid long trips and night driving until fixed.

title: High Alternator AC Ripple — Flickering Lights, Module Resets
symptom_short: Lights flicker; electronics glitch; random resets

likely_causes.cause: Alternator diode failure causing high AC ripple
likely_causes.notes: High ripple can damage sensitive ECUs and sensors.

likely_causes.cause: Loose alternator ground/power connections

recommended_checks: Measure AC ripple at battery with meter set to AC volts (healthy usually very low).
Inspect alternator output cable and grounds for corrosion/loose bolts.
Replace alternator if ripple is excessive and symptoms match.
safety_warning: Driving with high ripple can slowly damage electronics; repair as soon as possible.

title: Headlights Dim at Idle but Brighten When Revving
symptom_short: Dimming at stop; brighter with RPM

likely_causes.cause: Weak alternator output at low RPM
High load at idle (blower, rear defrost, heated seats)
Poor grounds causing voltage drop

recommended_checks: Turn off loads and see if dimming improves.
Perform voltage drop test on grounds (battery negative to engine block/chassis).
Test alternator output and battery condition.
safety_warning: Severe flicker can precede alternator failure and potential engine stall.

title: Engine/Chassis Ground Strap Failure — Random Electrical Issues
symptom_short: Random sensor codes, dim lights, weird behavior

likely_causes.cause: Corroded/broken ground strap between engine and chassis
Loose battery negative terminal or chassis ground point

recommended_checks: Inspect ground straps for broken strands/corrosion/missing bolts.
Clean ground points to bare metal and re-tighten.
Do a voltage drop test during cranking and with loads ON.
safety_warning: Bad grounds can cause ECU damage and sudden shutdowns.

title: Main Fuse / Fusible Link Blows Repeatedly
symptom_short: Large fuse blows as soon as replaced

likely_causes.cause: Direct short to ground in high-current circuit (starter/alternator/main feed)
likely_causes.notes: Often due to chafed cable or incorrect jump start.

recommended_checks: Do NOT install bigger fuse; locate short properly.
Inspect battery cables for rubbing/chafing near engine/transmission.
Check alternator output wire insulation and starter cable routing.
Use proper diagnostic methods (current-limited supply, short finder) if available.
safety_warning: High-current shorts can overheat wiring and start a fire. Do not drive until repaired.

title: Electrical Burning Smell Inside Cabin
symptom_short: Strong burning plastic / electrical odor under dash

likely_causes.cause: Overheated connector or wiring (high resistance connection)
likely_causes.notes: Common at blower motor resistor, ignition switch, power outlet.

likely_causes.cause: Short circuit in seat heater/window/steering column wiring

recommended_checks: Turn off non-essential loads (HVAC, heaters, chargers) immediately.
Look for visible smoke/melted plastic (safe distance).
Pull over safely and shut vehicle off if smell is intense.
Have wiring inspected before using the affected circuit again.
safety_warning: This can precede an interior fire. Stop and exit if smoke is visible.

title: No Communication with OBD-II Scanner
symptom_short: Scanner won’t connect; possible network/power issue

likely_causes.cause: Blown OBD port power fuse (often shares cigarette lighter circuit)
likely_causes.notes: Very common after plugging accessories.

likely_causes.cause: CAN bus issue preventing module communication

recommended_checks: Check if 12V power outlet/cigarette lighter works; if not, check its fuse.
Inspect OBD connector pins for damage/corrosion.
If multiple modules show no comm, suspect CAN network problem.
safety_warning: If multiple warning lights are on with no comm, critical systems may be affected.

title: CAN Bus Failure — Many Warning Lights & Random Faults
symptom_short: Multiple lights, shifting issues, ABS/TC/airbag warnings together
symptom_patterns: abs and traction and airbag lights

likely_causes.cause: CAN high/low shorted to ground or power
likely_causes.notes: Wiring chafed or water intrusion.

likely_causes.cause: Failed module pulling down the bus
likely_causes.notes: A single bad module can disrupt communication.

likely_causes.cause: Water intrusion/corrosion in connectors or junction blocks

recommended_checks: If available, measure CAN resistance with power OFF (~60 ohms across CAN H/L is common).
Inspect known water-intrusion areas (kick panels, under seats, fuse boxes).
Unplug suspect modules one-by-one (advanced) to find the one dragging the network.
Scan with a tool that shows module topology and U-codes.
safety_warning: CAN failures can disable ABS/stability/airbags/transmission control — drive cautiously or tow if severe.

title: Body Control Module Issues — Random Locks/Windows/Lights
symptom_short: Windows/locks/wipers/lights behave randomly

likely_causes.cause: Water intrusion into BCM or connectors
likely_causes.notes: Check for wet carpet or musty smell.

likely_causes.cause: Broken wiring in door jamb harness
likely_causes.notes: Repeated door movement breaks conductors.

likely_causes.cause: Internal BCM failure (solder cracks/component damage)

recommended_checks: Scan for multiple unrelated body codes.
Inspect door boot wiring and check for cracked insulation.
Check for moisture under dash/kick panels; dry and repair leaks.
safety_warning: BCM issues can affect lighting and wipers (visibility) and sometimes immobilizer (no-start).

title: Immobilizer / Security No-Start
symptom_short: Crank/no start or no crank with security light
symptom_patterns: car won't start key not recognized

likely_causes.cause: Key transponder not recognized / key fob battery weak
likely_causes.notes: Try spare key or replace fob battery.

likely_causes.cause: Antenna/receiver issue near ignition or push-button area
Module sync or immobilizer fault
likely_causes.notes: May require reprogramming.

recommended_checks: Try spare key and/or replace key fob battery.
Use the backup start location (per owner’s manual).
Check for related DTCs in immobilizer/BCM.
Inspect for recent battery disconnect or low voltage events.
safety_warning: Do not attempt bypass methods; they can damage modules or violate laws in some regions.

title: Push-Button Start: Key Not Detected / No Start
symptom_short: Keyless system does not detect key
symptom_patterns: have to hold key near button

likely_causes.cause: Weak key fob battery
Radio interference or receiver antenna issue
likely_causes.notes: Often happens only in certain parking locations.

recommended_checks: Replace key fob battery.
Use backup start method described in the manual.
Test with spare fob if available.
safety_warning: If this happens after you shut the car off, you may be stranded; fix before long trips.

title: Dash Lights Flicker / Car Cuts Out Over Bumps
symptom_short: Power loss over bumps; may stall and restart

likely_causes.cause: Loose battery terminals or main power cable
Loose ECU/fuse box connector or failing main relay
Ground connection intermittent

recommended_checks: Check battery clamps tightness and inspect cables for broken strands.
Inspect under-hood fuse box for loose terminals or heat damage.
Perform wiggle test carefully (engine idling, safe area) to locate intermittent connection.
safety_warning: Sudden engine shutdown causes loss of power steering/brake assist — this is safety-critical.

title: One Headlight Out (Other Lights OK)
symptom_short: Single headlight not working

likely_causes.cause: Burned out bulb or LED module failure
Corroded connector or wiring at that headlamp
Failed headlight driver/module (on some systems)

recommended_checks: Check high beam vs low beam function.
Inspect connector for corrosion/overheating.
Swap bulb (if halogen) to confirm; for LED systems, check for TSBs.
safety_warning: Reduced visibility and higher risk at night — repair soon.

title: Both Headlights Out Suddenly
symptom_short: Both low beams or both headlights fail at once

likely_causes.cause: Blown fuse or headlight relay
Headlight switch or BCM control fault

recommended_checks: Check fuses/relays for low beam and headlight power.
Try high beams; if high works but low doesn’t, suspect low-beam circuit/fuse.
Scan BCM for lighting-related codes if available.
safety_warning: Do not drive at night without headlights.

title: Brake Lights Stuck On / Won’t Turn Off
symptom_short: Brake lights stay on; battery may drain
symptom_patterns: battery drains and brake lights on

likely_causes.cause: Brake pedal switch misadjusted or failed
likely_causes.notes: Often a simple switch near pedal.

likely_causes.cause: Pedal stopper pad missing/broken
likely_causes.notes: Small plastic/rubber pad can fall out.

recommended_checks: Check if pedal returns fully; inspect switch at pedal.
Look for missing stopper pad.
Unplug brake switch temporarily to prevent battery drain (temporary only).
safety_warning: Brake lights stuck on can confuse drivers behind you and drain the battery.

title: Turn Signal Hyper-Flash (Fast Blinking)
symptom_short: Turn signal blinks fast on one side

likely_causes.cause: Bulb out on that side
Incorrect LED retrofit without proper resistor/programming

recommended_checks: Walk around and confirm which lamp is out.
Replace bulb or repair socket/corrosion.
If LED retrofit, use correct load resistor or BCM coding if supported.
safety_warning: Signals are critical for safety — fix promptly.

title: Power Window Slow or Stuck
symptom_short: Window moves slowly or stops

likely_causes.cause: Dry/dirty window channels causing high load
likely_causes.notes: Friction overload can trip protection.

likely_causes.cause: Failing window regulator or motor
Broken wiring in door jamb

recommended_checks: Listen for motor sound; if motor runs but glass doesn’t move, regulator likely.
Inspect door boot wiring for breaks.
Clean/lubricate window channels with silicone-safe product.
safety_warning: Window stuck open is a security/weather issue; fix before heavy rain or freezing temps.

title: Door Lock Works Intermittently
symptom_short: One door sometimes won’t lock/unlock

likely_causes.cause: Weak door lock actuator
Broken wiring in door jamb harness

recommended_checks: Identify which door fails consistently.
Listen for faint actuator clicks.
Inspect door boot wiring for cracked conductors.
safety_warning: Lock failures are a security concern and can be critical for child safety.

title: Horn Not Working
symptom_short: Horn does not sound

likely_causes.cause: Blown horn fuse or failed horn relay
Failed horn unit or corroded connector
Clock spring issue (if horn on steering wheel and airbags lights also)
likely_causes.notes: May affect airbag circuits.

recommended_checks: Check fuse/relay first.
Test horn directly with 12V (advanced).
If airbag light + horn issue together, suspect clock spring and scan for codes.
safety_warning: A bad clock spring can affect airbag system — inspect promptly.

title: Wipers Not Working / Intermittent
symptom_short: Wipers stop, work intermittently, or only on one speed

likely_causes.cause: Wiper motor or linkage issue
Blown fuse/relay or BCM control fault
Bad multifunction switch (stalk)

recommended_checks: Check fuses and wiper relay.
Listen for motor sound; if motor runs but arms don’t move, linkage may be off.
Scan BCM for wiper-related codes if available.
safety_warning: Wiper failure is dangerous in rain/snow — fix before driving in bad weather.

title: HVAC Blower Works Only on Highest Speed
symptom_short: Fan only works on max

likely_causes.cause: Failed blower motor resistor or control module
likely_causes.notes: Classic symptom: only highest speed works.

likely_causes.cause: Overheated connector at resistor
likely_causes.notes: May show melted plug.

recommended_checks: Inspect resistor/module and connector for heat damage.
Replace resistor/module and repair connector if melted.
Check cabin filter and blower load to prevent repeat failure.
safety_warning: Limited defrost control can reduce visibility in cold/wet conditions.

title: Cigarette Lighter / Power Outlet Not Working
symptom_short: 12V socket dead; chargers won’t work

likely_causes.cause: Blown outlet fuse from overloaded accessory
Socket contamination/short (coin or metal object)

recommended_checks: Check outlet fuse (often same as OBD power).
Inspect inside socket for debris/metal objects.
Use correct-rated accessories.
safety_warning: Repeated fuse blowing suggests a short; don’t keep replacing fuses without inspection.

title: Battery Terminal Corrosion / High Resistance Connection
symptom_short: Hard start, intermittent power, charging issues

likely_causes.cause: Acid vapor corrosion at terminals
Loose terminal clamp
likely_causes.notes: Can cause stalls and no-crank.

recommended_checks: Clean terminals (proper battery-safe method) and tighten clamps.
Inspect cables for swelling/green corrosion inside insulation.
Apply terminal protectant after cleaning.
safety_warning: Loose terminals can cause arcing and heat — fire risk and sudden shutdown risk.

title: Overcharging — Voltage Too High (Battery Boils, Lights Bright)
symptom_short: Voltage high; battery smell, bulbs failing

likely_causes.cause: Failed alternator voltage regulator
likely_causes.notes: Can damage modules and battery.

likely_causes.cause: Incorrect battery type coding on smart charging systems
likely_causes.notes: Some vehicles require battery registration/coding.

recommended_checks: Measure running voltage; if persistently high, stop driving soon.
Replace alternator/regulator as needed.
If vehicle uses battery monitoring, ensure correct battery registration.
safety_warning: Overvoltage can destroy electronics and may cause battery venting; treat as urgent.

title: Voltage Drops When Accessories Turn On
symptom_short: Voltage dips when blower/defrost/AC activates

likely_causes.cause: Weak alternator or poor belt drive
High resistance in power or ground circuits
likely_causes.notes: Bad connections heat up under load.

recommended_checks: Check belt/tensioner condition.
Perform voltage drop tests on main power and grounds under load.
Load-test alternator and battery.
safety_warning: If voltage collapses while driving, the engine may stall; plan repairs soon.

title: Airbag / SRS Light On
symptom_short: Airbag warning light stays on

likely_causes.cause: Seat connector issue (under-seat wiring) or occupancy sensor
likely_causes.notes: Moving seat can stress connectors.

likely_causes.cause: Clock spring failure
likely_causes.notes: May also affect horn and steering wheel buttons.

likely_causes.cause: Low voltage events causing stored codes

recommended_checks: Scan SRS codes with an SRS-capable tool (generic OBD may not read).
Inspect under-seat connectors for looseness or corrosion.
If steering wheel functions/horn affected too, suspect clock spring.
safety_warning: Airbags may be disabled when the light is on. Repair promptly.

title: ABS Light On (ABS Disabled)
symptom_short: ABS warning light stays on

likely_causes.cause: Wheel speed sensor or wiring damage
Tone ring damage/corrosion
ABS module fault

recommended_checks: Scan ABS codes with capable scanner.
Inspect sensor wiring near wheels for rub-through.
Check if ABS activates unexpectedly or not at all.
safety_warning: Normal braking may still work, but ABS may be disabled; increase following distance on wet/icy roads.
